@antinucleon, @piiswrong: for the dropout states, there is a further problem: you need cuDNN to generate the size of the required states. This size is needed at shape inference time, but InferShape does not take in a OpContext &ctx argument needed to get the cuDNN stream needed as an argument for cudnnDropoutGetStatesSize. So even if you use the trick of hiding the dropout state in an output, there is still the shape inference problem.

@sxjscience: the major advantage of writing the CPU version as a standard C++ layer is that will automatically give full RNN support across all the MXNet language bindings, rather than having to rewrite this per language. Or what do you think?
@sbodenstein Since RNN is still evolving, fixing the computational structure at this early stage  may not be good. It becomes more difficult for us to add new functionalities.

@sxjscience: this is true, but certain core RNN algorithms are fixed (LSTM, GRU, etc) and will become standardized now that libraries like cuDNN have official versions. Having a CPU version across language bindings for these core algorithms would be super useful.

This of course doesn't stop you implementing more experimental stuff in Python.

@sbodenstein  We may need to add new training variants for even these standard RNNs. One example is the recently introduced ZoneOut(http://arxiv.org/abs/1606.01305), which may in the future be the standard training regularizer for RNN.

my  BATCH_SIZE is 320 and run the example on GTX980ti . Speed is about 410 samples/sec and after epoch0,train-accuracy = 0.37 .

@sinmaystar     in warp-ctc/build . You can use the command to find it:   find  /home/$USER/warp-ctc/   -name libwarpctc.so.  And it shows the message:  /home/a/warp-ctc/build/libwarpctc.so  .    Then you edit the ~/.bashrc,add the  line export LD_LIBRARY_PATH="/home/a/warp-ctc/build:/usr/local/cuda-7.5/lib64:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH"(this is my own path) to the end of the file.

@sbodenstein @antinucleon My concern is that resembles of dropout and batch normalization in RNN, which hasn't been included in CuDNN, will soon be standardized and we may need to add these new features to our C++ implementation. Also, RNN in TensorFlow is implemented by combining basic symbols (https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/master/tensorflow/python/ops/rnn_cell.py). Anyway, writing a C++ compatible version of CuDNNRNN will do nothing bad. We can still implement the wrapper in the script language.

@sxjscience The reason is that, most of samples have **ZERO** reward, which will bring down the gradient to zeros once it fits the zero reward transitions.

now, DataBatch will storage all type of data in NDArray at the _init_data() step.
because the init is just one time, and the getdata() call if more frequently.
when use them , the data will aslo be given in NDArray type in the original implementation,
we can save the change step, as well NDArrayIter can support gpu now.

I have asked xlvector before, here is the code:

import random

vocab = [str(x) for x in range(100, 1000)]

sw_train = open("sort.train.txt", "w")
sw_test = open("sort.test.txt", "w")
sw_valid = open("sort.valid.txt", "w")

for i in range(1000000):
    seq = " ".join([vocab[random.randint(0, len(vocab) - 1)] for j in range(5)])
    k = i % 50
    if k == 0:
        sw_test.write(seq + "\n")
    elif k == 1:
        sw_valid.write(seq + "\n")
    else:
        sw_train.write(seq + "\n")

sw_train.close()
sw_test.close()
sw_valid.close()

@luoruisichuan This function is not written by me, so I can only share some ideas of mine. Convolution with stride > 1 can do downsample and max pooling can also do downsample. If you just put the max pooling after the conv, the size of feature maps will decrease more faster. 

If you take a look into the [paper](http://www.cs.unc.edu/~wliu/papers/GoogLeNet.pdf) where GoogLeNet was proposed and look at the inception modules of it, you will understand that the DownsampleFactory is somewhat like the inception module where a multi-branch and concat strategy is used. 

By the way, in my understanding, the `pad=(1,1)` in conv means to zero-pad the feature maps with size 1 in height and width fed into conv.

Correct me if I am wrong.
Thanks.
